about.title: About PlantCure – Plant Disease Diagnosis System

system.title: What is PlantCure?
system.paragraph1: PlantCure is a modern web application designed to help farmers, gardeners, and plant enthusiasts easily identify plant diseases by selecting or entering visible symptoms. Instead of rule-based matching, PlantCure now stores all disease information in a structured MongoDB database.
system.paragraph2: When symptoms are entered, the system searches through the database and retrieves the most relevant disease along with symptoms, causes, and treatment steps, making diagnosis fast, accurate, and user-friendly.

matching.title: How Symptoms are Processed
matching.intro: When you enter symptoms about your plant, the system follows these steps:

steps.input: Input Collection: You provide information such as leaf spots, discoloration, curling, powdery texture, holes, or stem issues.
steps.search: Database Search: The system searches the MongoDB disease collection to find entries matching the provided symptoms.
steps.selection: Disease Selection: When multiple diseases match, the system selects the most relevant and specific result.
steps.result: Result Generation: The selected disease details are displayed with description, symptoms, prevention, and treatment.

impact.title: Why This Project Solves Real-World Problems

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: Users can diagnose plant diseases instantly without expert help or costly testing. This is extremely useful in rural or remote regions.

speed.title: Speed
speed.description: The system quickly retrieves accurate disease information, helping users take action before the disease spreads.

accuracy.title: Reliable Information
accuracy.description: All disease data is stored and managed in MongoDB, ensuring clean structure, accuracy, and easy updates.

education.title: Educational Value
education.description: The platform includes a complete disease library, helping users learn about plant issues, symptoms, causes, and treatments.

technical.title: Technical Details
technical.intro: PlantCure is developed using modern full-stack technologies:
items: React JS – Modular and interactive UI
Tailwind CSS – Modern and responsive styling
React Router – Smooth navigation between pages
Node.js & Express.js – Backend API for symptoms and disease data
MongoDB – Database storing all disease information

contact.note: This project is created to help users diagnose plant diseases quickly using a clean and organized MongoDB database.

tomatoEarlyBlight.name: Early Blight
tomatoEarlyBlight.description: Early blight is a common fungal disease that affects tomato plants. It typically appears as brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves, causing them to yellow and die.
tomatoEarlyBlight.prevention: Use disease-resistant varieties. Rotate crops annually. Water at the base of plants, avoiding wetting leaves. Apply mulch to prevent soil splash.
tomatoEarlyBlight.cure: Remove infected leaves immediately. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Ensure proper spacing between plants for air circulation.

tomatoLateBlight.name: Late Blight
tomatoLateBlight.description: Late blight is a devastating fungal disease that can destroy entire tomato crops. It causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits.
tomatoLateBlight.prevention: Plant disease-resistant varieties. Avoid overhead watering. Ensure good air circulation. Monitor cool, wet weather that favors disease.
tomatoLateBlight.cure: Remove and destroy all infected plants immediately. Apply fungicides containing mefenoxam or chlorothalonil. Do not compost infected material.

tomatoSeptoria.name: Septoria Leaf Spot
tomatoSeptoria.description: Septoria leaf spot causes small, circular spots with dark borders and light centers on tomato leaves. It can defoliate plants if left untreated.
tomatoSeptoria.prevention: Use disease-free seeds. Rotate crops. Avoid working with wet plants. Remove plant debris at the end of the season.
tomatoSeptoria.cure: Remove infected leaves. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper. Improve air circulation around plants.

tomatoBacterialSpot.name: Bacterial Spot
tomatoBacterialSpot.description: Bacterial spot creates small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves, stems, and fruits. The spots may have yellow halos and can cause leaf drop.
tomatoBacterialSpot.prevention: Use disease-free seeds and transplants. Rotate crops. Avoid working with wet plants. Sanitize tools between uses.
tomatoBacterialSpot.cure: Remove infected plant parts. Apply copper-based bactericides. Avoid overhead irrigation.

wheatStripeRust.name: Stripe Rust
wheatStripeRust.description: Stripe rust appears as yellow-orange pustules arranged in stripes along wheat leaves. Severe infections can drastically reduce grain yield.
wheatStripeRust.prevention: Plant rust-resistant varieties. Monitor fields regularly. Apply preventive fungicides during favorable conditions. Remove volunteer wheat plants.
wheatStripeRust.cure: Apply fungicides containing tebuconazole, propiconazole, or azoxystrobin. Treat early for best results.

wheatLeafBlight.name: Leaf Blight
wheatLeafBlight.description: Leaf blight causes brown, elongated lesions on wheat leaves, often starting at the tips. It reduces photosynthesis and grain quality.
wheatLeafBlight.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Practice crop rotation. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization. Ensure proper field drainage.
wheatLeafBlight.cure: Apply fungicides containing propiconazole or tebuconazole. Remove infected plant debris after harvest.

generalPowderyMildew.name: Powdery Mildew
generalPowderyMildew.description: Powdery mildew shows up as white or gray powdery spots on leaves, stems, and sometimes flowers. It thrives in humid areas with poor air circulation.
generalPowderyMildew.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Ensure proper spacing. Water at the base of plants. Prune to improve airflow and avoid overhead watering.
generalPowderyMildew.cure: Remove infected plant parts. Apply fungicides containing sulfur, neem oil, or potassium bicarbonate. Improve air circulation.

generalRootRot.name: Root Rot
generalRootRot.description: Root rot causes roots to become brown, mushy, and decayed. Plants may wilt, grow slowly, and eventually die, especially in soggy soil.
generalRootRot.prevention: Ensure proper drainage. Avoid overwatering. Use well-draining soil. Rotate crops and remove plant debris. Avoid planting in waterlogged areas.
generalRootRot.cure: Remove affected plants. Improve soil drainage. Treat remaining plants with fungicides containing thiophanate-methyl or azoxystrobin and reduce watering.

generalLeafMiner.name: Leaf Miner
generalLeafMiner.description: Leaf miners create winding, white or brown trails on leaves as larvae feed between leaf layers. This damage reduces photosynthesis and can cause leaf drop.
generalLeafMiner.prevention: Use floating row covers. Monitor plants regularly. Remove affected leaves early. Encourage beneficial insects and practice crop rotation.
generalLeafMiner.cure: Remove and destroy infested leaves. Apply insecticides containing spinosad or neem oil. Release beneficial insects like parasitic wasps.

potatoEarlyBlight.name: Potato Early Blight
potatoEarlyBlight.description: Early blight on potatoes causes dark brown spots with concentric rings on leaves, leading to premature defoliation and reduced tuber yield.
potatoEarlyBlight.prevention: Use certified disease-free seed potatoes. Rotate crops. Avoid overhead irrigation. Apply mulch to prevent soil splash.
potatoEarlyBlight.cure: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Remove infected foliage and ensure proper plant spacing.

riceLeafBlight.name: Rice Leaf Blight
riceLeafBlight.description: Rice leaf blight creates brown, elongated lesions on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and grain yield. It is commonly caused by bacterial or fungal pathogens.
riceLeafBlight.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Practice proper water management. Avoid excessive nitrogen. Remove infected plant debris.
riceLeafBlight.cure: Apply appropriate fungicides or bactericides based on the pathogen. Remove infected material and improve field drainage.

cottonBacterialBlight.name: Cotton Bacterial Blight
cottonBacterialBlight.description: Bacterial blight causes angular, water-soaked spots on cotton leaves that turn brown and may lead to defoliation, reducing yield.
cottonBacterialBlight.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Rotate crops. Plant disease-free seeds. Sanitize equipment and avoid working with wet plants.
cottonBacterialBlight.cure: Apply copper-based bactericides. Remove and destroy infected plant parts. Avoid overhead irrigation.

roseBlackSpot.name: Rose Black Spot
roseBlackSpot.description: Black spot is a common fungal disease of roses, causing circular black spots with fringed edges on leaves, which then yellow and drop.
roseBlackSpot.prevention: Plant resistant varieties. Water at the base, not on leaves. Ensure good air circulation, remove fallen leaves, and prune regularly.
roseBlackSpot.cure: Remove infected leaves. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil, myclobutanil, or neem oil. Improve air circulation.

chiliAnthracnose.name: Chili Anthracnose
chiliAnthracnose.description: Anthracnose causes sunken, dark spots on chili fruits and leaves. It leads to fruit rot and major yield loss, especially in humid weather.
chiliAnthracnose.prevention: Use disease-free seeds. Rotate crops. Avoid overhead watering. Ensure proper spacing and remove debris after harvest.
chiliAnthracnose.cure: Remove infected fruits and leaves. Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or azoxystrobin. Improve air circulation.
